para.p: This note is a collection of results on Banach algebras whose proofs do not require the machinery of integrating functions that take values in Banach spaces, and that do not require the algebra to be commutative.

Unless we say otherwise, every vector space we talk about is taken to be over
C
. A Banach algebra is a Banach space
A
that is also an algebra satisfying
≤
∥
⁢ A B
∥
⁢
∥ A ∥
∥ B ∥
for
∈
A , B
A
. We say that
A
is unital if there is a nonzero element
∈ I A
such that
=
⁢ A I
A
and
=
⁢ I A
A
for all
∈ A A
, called a identity element. If
X
is a Banach space, let
⁢ B
( X )
denote the set of bounded linear operators
→ X X
, and let
⁢
B 0
( X )
denote the set of compact linear operators
→ X X
(to be compact means that the image of each bounded set is precompact).
⁢ B
( X )
is a unital Banach algebra.
⁢
B 0
( X )
is a Banach algebra, but it is unital if and only if
X
is finite dimensional.

An ideal of a Banach algebra
A
is a vector subspace
I
such that

Math.text: formulae@(I * A subset-of-or-equals I, A * I subset-of-or-equals I)

para.p:
We define the algebra quotient
/ A I
by

Math.text: A / I = conditional-set@(A + I, A element-of A)

para.p: and define

Math.text: (A + I) * (B + I) = A * B + I

para.p:
this makes sense because
I
is an ideal. We define a seminorm on
/ A I
by

Math.text: norm@(A + I) = (infimum _ (S element-of I))@(norm@(A - S))

para.p: we call this the quotient seminorm. In the following theorem we show that if the ideal is closed then this seminorm is a norm.

If
I
is a closed ideal in a Banach algebra
A
, then
/ A I
is a Banach algebra with the quotient norm.

Suppose that
=

0
. This means

Math.text: (infimum _ (S element-of I))@(norm@(A - S)) = 0

If
X
is a Banach space, then
⁢

( X )

⁢

→ X X
(to be finite rank means to have a finite dimensional image).
⁢

X
is finite dimensional. The closure of

( X )

B 0
( X )

⁢
B 0
( X )
we say that the Banach space
X
has the approximation property.)

A Banach algebra
A
is in particular a Banach space, and thus
⁢ B
( A )
is itself a Banach algebra with the operator norm. The left regular representation is the map
: L
→ A
⁢ B
( A )
defined by

Math.text: formulae@(L * A * B = list@(A * B, A), B element-of A)

para.p:
It is apparent that
L
is an algebra homomorphism, and for
∈
A , B
A

Math.text: norm@(L * A * B) = norm@(A * B) less= norm@(A) * norm@(B)

showing that
≤

( A )

Math.text: (norm@(A)) _ 0 = norm@(L * A) = (supremum _ (norm@(B) less= 1))@(norm@(L * A * B)) less= norm@(A)

para.p:
Check that
L
is injective, from which it follows that
∥ ⋅
∥ 0

A
. On the other hand,

Math.text: norm@(A) = norm@(L * A * I) less= norm@(L * A) * norm@(I) = (norm@(A)) _ 0 * norm@(I)

para.p: Therefore,

Math.text: (norm@(A)) _ 0 less= norm@(A) less= norm@(I) * (norm@(A)) _ 0

para.p:
so
∥ ⋅ ∥
and
∥ ⋅
∥ 0
are equivalent norms on
A
, and thus for most purposes anything we say using one can be said just as well using the other. We decree that if we are talking about a unital Banach algebra then its norm is such that
=
∥ I ∥
1
. Then,
L
is an isometry.

<
1
of the identity element in a unital Banach algebra remains in the multiplicative group. 1 1 footnote 1 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 249, Theorem 10.7.

In Theorem we proved that a perturbation of the identity element remains in the multiplicative group. We now prove that for any element of the multiplicative group, a sufficiently small perturbation of this element remains in the multiplicative group, i.e. that the multiplicative group is an open set. 3 3 footnote 3 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 253, Theorem 10.11.

Moreover,

, the spectral radius is equal to a limit of norms. 4 4 footnote 4 Gert K. Pedersen, Analysis Now, revised printing, p. 131, Theorem 4.1.13. This proof does not use the holomorphic functional calculus, while Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 253, Theorem 10.13 does. That is, to read Pedersen’s proof one does not have to make sense of integrals of functions taking values in a Banach space, while to read Rudin’s one does.

If

para.p:
Using the fact that the spectrum of any element of a unital Banach algebra is nonempty, one can prove the Gelfand-Mazur theorem, which states that if
A
is a unital Banach algebra for which every nonzero element is invertible, then there is an isometric algebra isomorphism
→ A C
. 5 5 footnote 5 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 255, Theorem 10.14.

For
> N M
,

Math.text: norm@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * A ^ n) - ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ M)@(alpha _ n * A ^ n)) = norm@(((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * A ^ n)) less= ((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * norm@(A ^ n)) less= ((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * (norm@(A)) ^ n) less= ((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * r ^ n)
norm@(((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * A ^ n) - ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ M)@(alpha _ n * A ^ n))
norm@(((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * A ^ n))
((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * norm@(A ^ n))
((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * (norm@(A)) ^ n)
((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * r ^ n)

para.p:
Because the radius of convergence of
∑

>
r
, it follows that the above sums tend to

as

( A )
A
. Define

Math.text: P _ n * open-interval@(A, lambda) = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(lambda ^ k * A ^ (n - k))

para.p: giving

Math.text: (A - lambda * I) * P _ n * open-interval@(A, lambda) = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(lambda ^ k * A ^ ((n - k) + 1) - lambda ^ (k + 1) * A ^ (n - k)) = A ^ (n + 1) - lambda ^ (n + 1) * I

para.p: We have

Math.text: f * A - f * lambda * I = ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(alpha _ n * (A ^ n - lambda ^ n * I)) = (A - lambda * I) * ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda))

para.p:
But if
≤
| λ |
r
then

Math.text: norm@(P _ n * open-interval@(A, lambda)) less= ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@((absolute-value@(lambda)) ^ k * norm@(A ^ (n - k))) less= ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@((absolute-value@(lambda)) ^ k * (norm@(A)) ^ (n - k)) less= ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ n)@(r ^ n) = (n + 1) * r ^ n

para.p:
and if
> N M
then

Math.text: norm@(((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda)) - ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ M)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda))) = norm@(((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda))) less= ((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * norm@(P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda))) less= ((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * n * r ^ (n - 1))
norm@(((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda)) - ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ M)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda)))
norm@(((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda)))
((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * norm@(P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda)))
((sum _ (n = M + 1)) ^ N)@(absolute-value@(alpha _ n) * n * r ^ (n - 1))

para.p:
and as
∑

r
this tends to

as

Math.text: ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda)) element-of A

para.p: and hence

Math.text: f * A - f * lambda * I = (A - lambda * I) * ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(alpha _ n * P _ (n - 1) * open-interval@(A, lambda)) element-of A

If
A

Math.text: sigma * (A - z _ 0 * I) = sigma * A - z _ 0

para.p:
Let
=

then by Theorem ,

Math.text: lambda - z _ 0 = f * lambda element-of sigma * f * A = sigma * (A - z _ 0 * I)

para.p: so

Math.text: sigma * A - z _ 0 subset-of-or-equals sigma * (A - z _ 0 * I)

para.p:

para.p: so

Math.text: sigma * B + z _ 0 subset-of-or-equals sigma * A

para.p: i.e.

Math.text: sigma * (A - z _ 0) subset-of-or-equals sigma * A - z _ 0
